intro: Opopanax persicus, commonly known as the Persian opopanax, is a rare and ancient plant native to the high plateaus of eastern Iran. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes frankincense and myrrh, and is characterized by its aromatic resinous exudates. The plant produces a dark, fragrant resin that has been used for medicinal and aromatic purposes for thousands of years. Its botanical features include a tall, slender stem with compound leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a critically endangered species.
